French PM Lecornu faces a high-stakes budgetary dilemma
subhead: Sébastien Lecornu is holding talks with political leaders from the right and the left after Parliament failed to pass the 2026 budget bill. He could propose a special law to avoid a shutdown from Monday, and is considering trying to force through a compromise bill.

subhead: US forces have launched strikes on boats it says, without providing evidence, were trafficking drugs in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean since September. More than 100 people have been killed.

title: Gaza: The Latin patriarch of Jerusalem honors Christians, who remain 'steadfast' in a 'sea of destruction'
subhead: Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa, head of the Catholic Church in the Holy Land, made another visit to the Gaza Strip to celebrate Christmas Mass. The vast majority of the Christian community, now down to just 600 people, is still sheltering within the parish.

title: British singer Chris Rea, known for 'Driving Home for Christmas,' dies at 74
subhead: The singer-songwriter 'passed away peacefully in hospital earlier today following a short illness,' his family said in a press release on Monday.

title: Celebrate the season with Le Monde in English's most beloved holiday movies

Giorgia Meloni: Neo-fascist or far right? Why Italian PM's tenure raises questions among political experts
subhead: The Italian prime minister has been in power now for three years. Italy's political experts question the normalization of this leader, who comes from a neo-fascist background. Has her tenure really been accompanied by a moderation of her political views?

title: Madagascar's metalheads lead charge of anger: 'It's easier to make yourself heard when you scream'
subhead: After three weeks of protest, Madagascar's Generation Z succeeded in toppling those in power on October 14. The uprising drew much of its strength from countercultural circles, chief among them the island's vibrant metal scene. Heirs to a long tradition, Madagascar's metalheads condemn poverty, inequality and the regime's incompetence.
byline: By Jean-Philippe Rémy (Antananarivo, Madagascar, special correspondent)

title: Disneyland Paris at 40: When Mickey Mouse said 'bonjour' to Paris
subhead: On December 18, 1985, the Walt Disney Company approved the construction of its first European theme park in Marne-la-Vallée, about 30 kilometers east of Paris. The prime minister secured the deal after tough negotiations between envoys from the Socialist government and an American corporation seen as the embodiment of ruthless capitalism.
